body:
also I dig the formatting choices overall, for this one it works if the left side starts with parenthesis, so probably this is what it should do (at least this is how I'll try to work around it):

```python
def test_of_type(self):
    (
        JuniorEngineer,
        Company,
        companies,
        Manager,
        Employee,
        employees,
        Engineer,
        Programmer,
    ) = (
        self.classes.JuniorEngineer,
        self.classes.Company,
        self.tables.companies,
        self.classes.Manager,
        self.classes.Employee,
        self.tables.employees,
        self.classes.Engineer,
        self.classes.Programmer,
    )

```

here's another variant, inside the "for" for a list comprehension:

```python
def foo():
    records = (
        (None, state_dict, params, mapper,
            connection, value_params, has_all_pks, has_all_defaults)
        for
        state, state_dict, params, mp,
        conn, value_params, has_all_pks,
        has_all_defaults in _collect_insert_commands(table, (
            (None, mapping, mapper, connection)
            for mapping in mappings),
            bulk=True, return_defaults=return_defaults,
            render_nulls=render_nulls
        )
    )

```

comes out as:

```python

def foo():
    records = (
        (
            None,
            state_dict,
            params,
            mapper,
            connection,
            value_params,
            has_all_pks,
            has_all_defaults,
        )
        for state, state_dict, params, mp, conn, value_params, has_all_pks, has_all_defaults in _collect_insert_commands(
            table,
            ((None, mapping, mapper, connection) for mapping in mappings),
            bulk=True,
            return_defaults=return_defaults,
            render_nulls=render_nulls,
        )
    )

```

issue.title: long dotted identifiers that are correct length are flattened out into too-long lines

labels.name: R: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: F: linetoolong
labels.description: Black makes our lines too long

issue.body:
Operating system: fedora 29
Python version: 3.7.0
*Black* version: 18.9b0
Does also happen on master: yup

Sorry, it's me again from #656, another variant on Black taking code that *is* pep8 and making it *not* pep8, a series of dotted identifiers are flattened out to be too long when no change was required to keep it pep8:

```python
dbapi = None


class FooTest:
    def test_result(self):
        self.assertEqual(
            [
                c[2]
                for c in dbapi.connect.return_value.
                cursor.return_value.execute.mock_calls
            ],
            [
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": False},
                {"direct": True},
            ],
        )

```

black makes it:

```python
dbapi = None


class FooTest:
    def test_result(self):
        self.assertEqual(
            [
                c[2]
                for c in dbapi.connect.return_value.cursor.return_value.execute.mock_calls
            ],
            [
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": True},
                {"direct": False},
                {"direct": True},
            ],
        )

```

this one I can't work around with parenthesis, I have to assign to an intermediary variable to work around which is fairly non-ideal (ill add parenthesis).

if black had options to change all this, then I'd use those, but your philosophy is to not have any options :)  so...posting an issue seems more critical.

body: Yes, I think we should add parentheses and produce the formatting in https://github.com/ambv/black/issues/656#issuecomment-450989281.
This is quite similar to #610 as well

issue.title: Split the left side of an assignment if longer
issue.body:
Operating system: GNU/Linux
Python version: 3.6
*Black* version: 18.9b0
Does also happen on master: yes

In our codebase, we sometimes have long tuple unpacking in one assignment, like:

```
a, b, c, d, e, [...], z = args
```

Since these run well over the line length limit, black transform them to:

```
a, b, c, d, e, [...], z = (
    args
)
```

But these still run over the limit.

It would be much better to convert to:

```
(
    a,
    b,
    c,
    d,
    e,
    [...],
    z,
) = args
```

Which black already does if you parenthesize the left side.

(I understand these long assignments are bad, but this is a large codebase and the refactoring necessary to stop this is non-trivial)

issue.title: unpack to varialbes more than line-length chars can be flake8 uncompatible

labels.name: T: style
labels.description: What do we want Blackened code to look like?

issue.body:
given:
```
test_1234567890_1, test_1234567890_2, test_1234567890_3, test_1234567890_4, test_1234567890_5, \
    test_1234567890_6, test_1234567890_7 = range(7)
```

run:
`black --safe -S -l 100 file.py`

got:
```
test_1234567890_1, test_1234567890_2, test_1234567890_3, test_1234567890_4, test_1234567890_5, test_1234567890_6, test_1234567890_7 = range(
    7
)
```

expect:
```
(
    test_1234567890_1,
    test_1234567890_2,
    test_1234567890_3,
    test_1234567890_4,
    test_1234567890_5,
    test_1234567890_6,
    test_1234567890_7,
) = range(7)
```

Howdy! Sorry you're having trouble. To expedite your experience,
provide some basics for me:

Operating system: Ubuntu 16.04.6 LTS
Python version: 3.7.2
*Black* version: 19.3b0
Does also happen on master: yes

To answer the last question, you have two options:
1. Use the online formatter at https://black.now.sh/?version=master, which will use the latest master branch.
2. Or run black on your machine:
    * create a new virtualenv (make sure it's the same Python version);
    * clone this repository;
    * run `pip install -e .`;
    * make sure it's sane by running `python setup.py test`; and
    * run `black` like you did last time.

issue.title: add parentheses around tuple unpack assignment
Black adds line unnecessary line breaks on tuple expansion
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

Black adds line breaks on tuple expansion even when the line length is under the allotted limit.

**To Reproduce**

Given the following snippet:

```py
def do_something(values):
    ( a2, t0, t1, ) = values

    j = [1,
         2,
         3
    ]

    # Dummy code follows:
    if a2 < 0:
        return 0
    elif t1 == t0:
        return 1
    else:
        return 2
```

Using

```
black test_black.py --target-version py39
```

Black formats it to:

```py
def do_something(values):
    (
        a2,
        t0,
        t1,
    ) = values

    j = [1, 2, 3]

    # Dummy code follows:
    if a2 < 0:
        return 0
    elif t1 == t0:
        return 1
    else:
        return 2
```

I understand that this is probably a consequence of #656 , but I don't see this choice being described in [Black the code style](https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/the_black_code_style/current_style.html). It's the opposite of the [How Black wraps lines](https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/the_black_code_style/current_style.html#how-black-wraps-lines) example.

How is 

```py
    (
        a2,
        t0,
        t1,
    ) = values
```

More readable than

```py
    ( a2, t0, t1, ) = values
```

Also:

> If a data structure literal (tuple, list, set, dict) or a line of from imports cannot fit in the allotted length, its always split into one element per line.

The `    ( a2, t0, t1, ) = values` line is clearly under the allotted length, so I don't understand why the line breaks were added.

**Expected Output**

Given that the line length is under the limit, I expect Black to just add parentheses and a trailing comma:

```py
    (a2, t0, t1,) = values
```

**Environment**

- Black's version:

```
$ black --version
black, 23.7.0 (compiled: yes)
Python (CPython) 3.8.10
```
- OS and Python version:

```
$ python3 --version
Python 3.8.10

$ lsb_release -a
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 20.04.5 LTS
Release:        20.04
Codename:       focal
```

Same behaviour with Python 3.11.2 and Ubuntu 23.04
